'''Lance Wyman''' (b. [[Newark, New Jersey]], 1937<ref name = "WebEsteem">[http://art.webesteem.pl/9/wyman_en.php Case Study: Lance Wyman], ''WebEsteem Art & Design Magazine'', 2004</ref>) is an American graphic designer. He is known for such work as the logo of the [[1968 Summer Olympic Games]] and the route map of the [[Washington Metro]].
==Life and career== Wyman, the son of a commercial fisherman and a typist,<ref name = "WaPo">Dana Hedgpeth, "[http://www.washingtonpost.com/local/commuting/after-more-than-30-years-metro-map-is-being-redesigned-by-creator-lance-wyman/2011/05/31/AGeyD4IH_story.html After more than 30 years, Metro map is being redesigned by creator Lance Wyman]", washingtonpost.com, June 4, 2011; printed as "An icon's midlife facelift: Metro map must be updated, so its creator goes back to the drawing board", ''The Washington Post'', June 5, 2011, p. A1.</ref> grew up in [[Kearny, New Jersey]], where he worked in the factories during summers to pay for college. He acquired an appreciation for the "no-nonsense functional aesthetic of the sea and the factories", which he has described as "an important influence in my approach to design."<ref name = "WebEsteem" /> He graduated from the [[Pratt Institute]] with a degree in industrial design in 1960. The subject of [[graphic design]] was just being introduced in American universities at the time; when Wyman met a student who studied [[logo]] design with [[Paul Rand]] at [[Yale]], he wanted to design logos.<ref name = "WebEsteem" />
Wyman began his career in [[Detroit, Michigan]], at [[General Motors]], where he worked on a packaging system for [[Delco]] automotive parts that unified 1,200 different packages. Later, he moved to the office of [[William Schmidt]], where he produced the graphics for the American pavilion at a 1962 trade fair in [[Zagreb, Yugoslavia]].<ref name = "WebEsteem" />
In 1963, Wyman moved to New York, where he joined the [[George Nelson]] firm. He designed the graphics for the [[Chrysler]] Pavilion at the [[New York World's Fair]]. He later reported that devising a "pointing hand" theme logo and adapting it to the site directional signs convinced him that logos could play a more important role in an overall design program.<ref name = "WebEsteem" /> In 1966, he participated in a design competition for the graphics for the 1968 [[1968 Summer Olympics|Mexico Olympic Games]]. His "Mexico68" logotype was the winner, and launched his career. Wyman remained in Mexico for four and one-half years, following his Olympic work with development of graphic programs for the [[Mexico City Metro]] and the [[1970 FIFA World Cup|1970 World Cup]] competition.<ref name = "WebEsteem" /><ref name = "WaPo" />
After returning to New York in 1971, Wyman formed a partnership with Bill Cannan (Wyman & Cannan). In 1979, he established his own firm, Lance Wyman Ltd. He has also taught corporate and wayfinding design at [[Parsons School of Design]] since 1973.<ref name = "WebEsteem" />
==Work== Wyman, who has been described as a "rock star" of graphic arts,<ref name = "WaPo" /> made his reputation when he designed the logo for the [[1968 Summer Olympic Games]]. He has also designed icons for museums and many other institutions, individualized signs for buildings at the U.S. [[Smithsonian National Zoological Park|National Zoo]], and many other symbols. Stepping outside his usual genre, he designed a poster for the 2008 Barack Obama presidential campaign.<ref>Steven Heller, "[http://imprint.printmag.com/branding/wyman-in-ireland/ Wyman in Ireland]", ''Imprint''. Accessed 2011.06.15.</ref> Perhaps his most enduring design is the stylized route map he devised for the [[Washington Metro]] in the mid-1970s, showing routes, stations, transfer points, and certain landmarks in a clear fashion, although distances are not to scale.<ref name = "WaPo" /> In 2011, Wyman was called on to design a new Metro map, able to depict planned new lines and route orientations, as well as some station names that have been expanded to the point of being cumbersome.<ref>Steve Delahoyde, [http://www.mediabistro.com/unbeige/lance-wyman-difficult-task-of-re-designing-his-original-dc-metro-map_b14488 Lance Wyman Difficult Task of Re-Designing His Original DC Metro Map], Mediabistro.com, Unbeige, June 6, 2011.</ref><ref>Dana Hedgpeth, "Metro's Main Designer", ''Express'' (Washington, D.C.), June 6, 2011, p. 12.</ref> It is one of the few occasions in which the original designer has a chance to revise his own creation.<ref name = "WaPo" />
